chapter.title: Knowing &osc;, the Command Line Tool
chapter.remark: toms 2017-08-16: http://docserv.suse.de/documents/Open_Build_Service/obs-best-practices/html/cha.obs.best-practices.oscexamples.html#id17157 osc, the Python command line client

sect1.title: Installing and Configuring
sect1.para: To work with &obs; install the &osccmd; command line tool from your preferred distributions or from the &obsa; project openSUSE:Tools. The tool runs on any modern Linux system and is available for different distributions, like CentOS, Debian, Fedora, SLE, &opensuse;, to name a few.
For &suse; related systems, install it with the zypper command (replace DISTRI with your distribution):
sect1.remark: toms 2017-08-16: Maybe add more information about installing osc on other distributions?
sect1.para: For other systems, use your preferred package manager.

As an alternative, use the &appimg; file. An &appimg; file is a packaged application and its dependencies which can run on many distributions. Download the file, save it in your ~/bin directory, and make the file executable.

sect1.title: Configuring &osc;
sect1.para: Usually, the default configuration is appropriate in most cases. There are some special configuration option which might be helpful if you have special needs.
